children.name: nutcase x
children.definition: nutcase/loony sb who behaves in acrazyand oftenamusingway and who has strange ideas: người điên , dở hơi ( rối loạn thần kinh )
examples: our old maths teacher was a real nutcase -- he used to eat chalk because he said it was good for your bones.
a bunch of loonies
in the 1960s, people thought that vegetarians were a bunch of loonies.

children.name: maniac x
children.definition: maniac/lunatic/ˈmeɪniæk, ˈluːnətɪk/  especiallyspokensomeone who behaves in a stupidly dangerous way:
examples: người điên
▪ ken drives like a maniac.
ken lái xe như thằng điên
▪ some lunatic threw a can of lighter fluid on the fire.
vài tên điên đã ném một bình xăng vào ngọn lửa

children.name: nut x
children.definition: nutđiên
examples: a lot of people think he’s a complete nut, but he’s actually quite harmless.
the woman sounds like a real nut.
sb is some kind/type of nut
he started asking me a lot of questions about my personal life. i think the guy’s some kind of nut.

children.name: nutter x
children.definition: nutter british informal sb who has strange ideas or who behaves in a strange and often frightening way: lập dị, gàn dở
examples: sometimes you get these nutters calling you at 3 o'clock in the morning.
burns can be a nutter - especially when he’s had a few drinks.
complete nutter
he’s a complete nutter. he’s got no sense whatsoever.

children.name: crazy a2
children.definition: crazy sb who is crazy does things that are extremely strange or stupid: điên, khùng
examples: ▪ my dad told me i was crazy to leave my job.
▪ you agreed to marry him? are you crazy?
▪ crazy drivers who cause accidents
▪ his friends thought he was crazy when he told them he was going to spend his entire vacation exploring a cave.
completely/totally crazy
▪ put that gun down! are you totally crazy
crazy to do sth
▪ you’re crazy to lend him all that money - you’ll never get it back.

children.name: be nuts x
children.definition: benutsalsobe crackersbritishspokeninformalto be crazy: dở hơi
examples: people will think you’re crackers if you go around talking to yourself like that.
the guy’s completely nuts! he goes around in nothing but a pair of shorts in the middle of winter.

children.name: mad b1
children.definition: mad/barmy british spoken crazy:điên/khùng
examples: you spent $190 on a pair of shoes? you must be mad!
completely mad/barmy
▪ monica’s new boyfriend is completely barmy. he calls her almost every day from australia.
mad/barmy to do something
▪ she’s mad to turn down an offer like that.
▪ i must have been mad to let myself become involved with someone like dennis.

children.name: be insane c1
children.definition: be insane/be out of your mind especially spoken you say sb is insane or out of their mind if they do sth or intend to do sth that is completely crazy:điên cuồng, mất trí
examples: anyone who would take a boat out in this weather must be insane.
tell the police? are you out of your mind?

children.name: need your head examined x
children.definition: need your head examined/ have taken leave of your senses say this when you think sb is crazy because they have done something that you do not approve of or agree with:
examples: a man who would give his fourteen-year-old son a motorcycle has obviously taken leave of his senses.
if you ask me, anyone who believes in ufos needs their head examined.

children.name: be out to lunch x
children.definition: be out to lunch/ be out of your tree informal sb who is out to lunch or out of their tree behaves in a strange, confused way and does not seem to know what is happening around them:mơ ngủ, mơ mộng
examples: our english teacher’s really out to lunch -- the class started five weeks ago and she hasn’t even asked our names yet.
he is quoted as saying privately that he thinks the former prime minister is ‘out of her tree’.

children.name: flaky x
children.definition: flaky especially us, informal sb who seems unable to think clearly or do what they should do, and behaves in a strange but often amusing way: tưng tửng
examples: ▪ christy was kind of flaky, but everyone liked her.
▪ you couldn’t trust sam to do anything important. he was too flaky.

children.name: be one sandwich short of a picnic x
children.definition: be one sandwich short of a picnicalsobe a couple of cans short of a six-packstrange and slightly crazy: ngớ ngẩn, gàn gàn
examples: i always thought toby was one sandwich short of a picnic. do you remember how he would sometimes work naked in the garden?
▪ come on. let’s face it - nobody trusts the guy because he’s at least one clown short of a circus.

children.name: have a screw loose x
children.definition: have a screw loose informal slightly crazy, often in an amusing way: lập dị
examples: ▪ ‘fernando can be really weird sometimes.’ ‘yeah, he’s got a screw loose, no question.’

children.name: sensible b1
children.definition: sensible sb who issensibleis unlikely to do anything stupid, because they judge situations well and make good decisions:biết điều, hiểu chuyện
examples: laura’s a pretty sensible girl. i don’t think she’d talk to strangers.
he’s one of the few sensible people on the council.
be sensiblespoken
be sensible - you can’t go out without a coat in this weather.
sensible about
people are far more sensible about what and how much they drink these days.

children.name: reasonable b2
children.definition: reasonable sb who is reasonable makes sensible decisions that arefairtoeveryone: biết điều, hiểu chuyện
examples: she’s usually very reasonable as a boss, but now and again her temper flares up.
let’s try and discuss this in a calm and reasonable way.
be reasonablespoken : nói năng hợp lý
be reasonable, paul - i’m only trying to help.

children.name: responsible b2
children.definition: responsible someone whois responsiblecan be trusted to do what they should do and to think about the results of their actions:có trách nhiệm
examples: we aim to educate our children to become socially responsible citizens.
i’m a responsible adult. i can make my own choices.
responsibly[adverb]
people should have their driving licences taken away if they can’t drive responsibly.

children.name: rational c1
children.definition: rational if sb isrational, their actions are based on a clear understanding of the facts of a situation, and are not influenced by their feelings or imagination :lý trí (khác với cảm xúc)
examples: ▪ taking action to defend yourself is a completely rational reaction if you’re being attacked.
▪ many of the patients have long histories of drug abuse, and they’re not always rational.
rationally[adverb]
▪ do people behave completely rationally when they vote in elections?

children.name: no-nonsense x
children.definition: no-nonsense direct anddealing with things in a practical way, without wasting time on things that do not matter:
examples: mathews is a no-nonsense veteran of the police department.
jason, with his no-nonsense approach, has been an asset to the project.

children.name: down-to-earth c1
children.definition: down-to-earth sb who isdown-to-earthis practical and honest, and does not think they are more important, more intelligent etc than other people:thực tế,không viễn vông
examples: she’s sophisticated, but also practical and down-to-earth.
people are surprised by what an unpretentious, down-to-earth guy he really is.

children.name: talk sense x
children.definition: talk sense especially spoken if sbtalks sense, they express sensible ideas or opinions that you agree with:nói năng hợp lý
examples: ▪ someone who could talk sense would get my vote, but most politicians don’t.

children.name: have your head screwed on x
children.definition: have your head screwed onbritish /have your headscrewed on rightamerican  use this about sb who will always behave sensibly in a difficult or confusing situation:
examples: don’t worry about sheila. she’s got her head screwed on.
anyone who can raise three such normal kids in hollywood must have their head screwed on right.

children.name: sane c2
children.definition: sane able to think clearly and likely to behave in a sensible way, especially when other people are not being sensible:sáng suốt
examples: i don’t think any sane person would take his threats seriously.
it was a relief to hear one sane voice among all the shouting and hysteria.
keep sb sane
exercise keeps me sane. if i didn’t exercise, the stress would get to me.

children.name: to try to persuade sb to behave sensibly
talk some sense into b2
children.definition: talk some sense intonói cho ai hiểu chuyện
examples: it took some time to calm him down and talk some sense into him.
will you try and talk some sense into him - he says he’s going to drop out of school.

children.name: get sb to see reason c2
children.definition: get sb to see reason to manage, with some difficulty, to persuade sb to behave sensibly by talking to them about the situation:nói cho ai hiểu vấn đề
examples: i just can’t get her to see reason.
eventually we managed to get the border guards to see reason.

children.name: bring sb to their senses x
children.definition: bring sb to their senses if something that has happened, especially an unpleasant surprise, brings sb to their senses, it makes them stop behaving in a stupid way and start behaving sensibly:sáng mắt
examples: seeing so many friends dying of drug-related illnesses was what brought me to my senses.
it took a lawsuit to bring them to their senses

children.name: to start behaving sensibly after not being sensible
come to your senses x
children.definition: come to your sensesnhận thức, hiểu ra
examples: he’d be crazy to leave liza - it’s about time he came to his senses.
her parents finally came to their senses and realized they couldn’t force her to marry someone she didn’t like.

children.name: see reason c2
children.definition: see reason/sense to start behaving sensibly after listening to advice or arguments from other people:hiếu được vấn đề
examples: i wish he’d see reason and stop putting so much pressure on me.
we talked to her for an hour, but we couldn't make her see sense.

children.name: get real x
children.definition: get real spoken use this to tell sb that they are not being sensible or practical, for example if they think that a difficult problem will be easy to deal with:thực tế
examples: get real. it’s pretty hard for a young woman on her first job to take a case of sexual harassment to court.
‘we could always ask dad for more money.’ ‘get real! we’d be grounded for a month!’

children.name: realistic b2
children.definition: realistic/practicalc2/pragmaticc2 having the ability to understand situations and to know what is or is not possible:thực tế
examples: she’s a practical manager who realizes that a happy workforce is also a productive one.
the people of this country need to be more realistic - you can’t have lower taxes as well as higher spending on health and pensions.
she is a tough, pragmatic, intuitive leader.
